page.title: 16STH WINGFIELD-CHANGING TIMES
page.content: {Mrs.Annie Burt,aged 82 years,who was {born at Manor Farm,Oakerthorpe and {still lives within a quarter of a mile {of her birth-place remembers her child {hood.} I had to rise at 04:45 to bring in the cattle and then help to milk them.Then the coal and sticks had to be fetched to light the fire.My next job was to take the milk on the cart to Wingfield Station to catch the 06:55 train for Sheffield where it was sold. Twenty pounds of butter had to then be churned by the children. Buttermilk was sold in the village for one penny a pint. My sister would plough from 06:00 until 18:00 with a break to change the horses at midday. We had 30 pigs to look after as well. Sometimes we would help the miners to cart coal at the nearby pit.
